results.title: DST July 09 presents...
results.brief_description: ACMI Digital Storytelling interviews the six participants of the Foundation of Young Australians workshop in July 2009. They are asked questions in regard to the process, what they learned and the experience of telling their stories. This is also intercut with footage from the actual workshop and serves as a behind the scenes documentary to capture the process of Digital Storytelling as well as the impact on the participants.

results.title: My family
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Dotoi, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: To Malcolm Dotoi, his family includes what he would call his extended family, his cousins and grandfather. They provide support, guidance and inspiration and have helped him to develop into a youth leader. His grandfather, a tribal elder, has taught Malcolm about his connection to the land and to the spiritual world and how all these things have contributed to who Malcolm is today.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Malcolm Dotoi, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Spirit, dance and connection = Spirit, dance & connection
results.creator_credit: Haryne Uta, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Dancing is a way of life, culture and part of our identity. Haryne Uta, a young Torres Strait Islander, started dancing from a very young age. He tells of his journey to not taking it very seriously to realising, under the guidance of his elders, how crucial dancing is to Haryne’s spiritual awakening. The stories of the dance awoke in Haryne a sense of pride and connection to the spiritual world, people and the land.

results.title: My "perfect" family
results.creator_credit: Ebonie Sadler-Small, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: While Ebonie Sadler-Small grew up with her grandmother, she attributes her entire family to the inspiring youth leader she is today. Ebonie feels that in not having a conventional family, she has gained an non-judgemental, adventurous and optimistic outlook on life. With her family and friends, Ebonie has been encouraged and supported and she feels this has given her the strength and confidence to achieve in life.

results.brief_description: Kat Hay provides her account of the Newcastle Floods of 2007, from the realisation that it was not an ordinary day to the feelings associated with returning home after everything was destroyed.

results.title: Change!
results.creator_credit: Tori Towney, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Tori Towney came from an encouraging and supportive family. Growing up, she resisted the urge to join her friends drinking and instead listened to the stories of her father, of his harsh and poor upbringing. When her mum encouraged her to move to Sydney and take up a scholarship at St Catherine’s, she grabbed this opportunity with both hands. Tori candidly shares what it was like to be away from home with no support network and how she overcame that and adapted to her new and exciting environment.

results.title: The Ties that bind
results.creator_credit: Milad Bardan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: It took seven years after the death of his mother and a political assassination in his birth country of Lebanon before Milad really got to know his father. This is a tribute to that man.

results.title: Hollywood Costume: Deborah Nadoolman Landis interview
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery, Sam Mapplebeck and ACMI

video_links.name: Hollywood Costume: Deborah Nadoolman Landis interview

results.brief_description:
Professor Deborah Nadoolman Landis, an Oscar nominated Hollywood costume designer (‘Raiders of the Lost Ark’, ‘Blues Brothers’, Michael Jackson’s ‘Thriller’) is the author of ‘Hollywood Costume’ (2012), the prize-winning catalogue for the exhibition, and ‘Hollywood Sketchbook: A Century of Costume Illustration’ (2012) among many other volumes. Landis received her Ph.D. from the Royal College of Art in London and is the Founding Director of the David C. Copley Center for Costume Design at the UCLA School of Theater, Film and Television.
In this interview she talks about the origins of the Hollywood Costume industry, working as a costume designer, what a costume designer does and the relationship between the director and the costume designer.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery, Sam Mapplebeck and ACMI

Landis received her Ph.D. from the Royal College of Art in London and is the Founding Director of the David C. Copley Center for Costume Design at the UCLA School of Theater, Film and Television.
In this interview she talks about the origins of the Hollywood Costume industry, working as a costume designer, what a costume designer does and the relationship between the director and the costume designer.

results.title: Ron Magliozzi and Jenny He interview: 'Tim Burton: The Exhibition'

video_links.name: Ron Magliozzi and Jenny He interview: 'Tim Burton: The Exhibition'

results.brief_description: Jenny He (Curatorial Assistant, Department of Film) and Ron Magliozzi (Assistant Curator, Department of Film) are co-organizers of the Tim Burton exhibition, from MoMa (The Museum of Modern Art) in New York. Here they are interviewed by Kate Warren, ACMI’s Assistant Curator, about their work on ‘Tim Burton: The Exhibition’. They take us through the process, from inception, through to collaborating with Tim Burton, of Burton’s work and the curatorial process. As well as viewing Tim Burton’s work from an artistic perspective, we also gain insight into the art of the curator and curatorial perspective.

results.title: One past eight futures "The making of"
results.brief_description: This mini-documentary takes us behind the scenes of the ‘One past eight futures’ Digital Storytelling workshop at ACMI. The participants of this particular workshop are eight young indigenous people who are part of the Indigenous Youth Leadership program. They discuss their stories, their participation in the workshop and what they have gained from the experience. The results are a social and cultural snapshot of Australia’s Indigenous youth, through their stories, their ties to the past and, mostly, their hopes for the future.
